question: Question_05_(b)
sols:
Since

\begin{align*}\displaystyle
b_3 = 7b_2 - 4b_1\end{align*} we have that

\begin{align*}
T(b_3) &= T(7b_2 - 4b_1)\\
&= 7T(b_2) - 4T(b_1) \\
&= 7 \left[\begin{array}{c} 1 \\ 2 \end{array}\right] - 4 \left[\begin{array}{c} 1 \\ 1 \end{array}\right] \\
&= \left[\begin{array}{c} 3 \\ 10 \end{array}\right]\end{align*}

To find the matrix of \emph{T} with respect to the standard basis, we
need to compute the image of each of these standard vectors.

\begin{align*}
T(e_1) &= T\left( \left[\begin{array}{c} 1 \\ 0 \end{array}\right] \right) \\
&= T(b_2) \\
&= \left[\begin{array}{c} 1 \\ 2 \end{array}\right]\end{align*} and

\begin{align*}
T(e_2) &= T\left( \left[\begin{array}{c} 0 \\ 1 \end{array}\right] \right) \\
&= T(b_2-b_1) \\
&= T(b_2) - T(b_1) \\
&= \left[\begin{array}{c} 1 \\ 2 \end{array}\right] - \left[\begin{array}{c} 1 \\ 1 \end{array}\right]
&= \left[\begin{array}{c} 0 \\ 1 \end{array}\right]\end{align*}

And so the matrix of \emph{T} in the standard basis is

\begin{align*}\left[\begin{array}{cc}
1 & 0 \\
2 & 1
\end{array}\right]\end{align*}

''Note that you can check that your result makes sense by verifying this
matrix on the vector \emph{b}\textsubscript{3}, indeed we have that''

\begin{align*}\left[\begin{array}{cc}
1 & 0 \\
2 & 1
\end{array}\right]\left[\begin{array}{c}
3 \\
4
\end{array}\right] = \left[\begin{array}{c}
3 \\
10
\end{array}\right]\end{align*}
hints:
To find \emph{T(b}\textsubscript{3}\emph{)} express
\emph{b}\textsubscript{3} as a linear combination of
\emph{b}\textsubscript{1} and \emph{b}\textsubscript{2}. Then use the
linearity of \emph{T}.

To find the matrix representation of \emph{T} you need to calculate
\emph{T(e}\textsubscript{1}\emph{)} and
\emph{T(e}\textsubscript{2}\emph{)}, where \emph{e}\textsubscript{1} =
{[}1,0{]} and \emph{e}\textsubscript{2} = {[}0,1{]}. Again, linear
combinations and linearity of \emph{T} will be your friends.
